 Hello, everyone.
Welcome to my talk.
Scan the code, and then I can show my slide.
OK.
So in this talk, I'll be talking about how much is the fish.
So essentially, it will be about raising
the cost for the attacker who wants to perform a reverse proxy
phishing operation.
So about me, quickly, my name is Kuba Gretzky,
also known as that evil jinx guy.
So quickly, I'm an offensive security tools developer.
I've developed several tools myself,
and this is what I basically do myself.
I'm as well an independent security researcher.
And I'm a hobby music producer, like a newbie DJ
recently starting out just learning how to mix stuff,
also a gamer, and an XMMO game hacker.
So game hacking was a big thing for me, like 15 years ago,
maybe.
It was all about reverse engineering and writing
automation software for massive online multiplayer games.
And I've learned most of the skills
I used till this day back then.
It is all very similar to actually bypassing
AV or EDR products.
It's very similar to bypassing anti-cheats in online games.
So I run a blog where I publish some of my research
that I do in my free time.
So you can check it out if you want.
I also made the Pound Drop, which
is like a tool that was made for red teamers
to host their payloads.
So it's a bit now forgotten, like for a few years.
So I may get back to it after I also handle all the Evil Jinx
updates myself.
And of course, I made Evil Jinx that you may already know.
By the way, how many people in the audience use Evil Jinx?
OK, how many people hate Evil Jinx?
Because I know there are a few of those people.
OK.
So anyway, the story behind Evil Jinx.
So it was released six years ago.
And back then, it was just like a very simple script,
Lua script, used with NGINX, a custom version of NGINX.
It was, I think, like an open Resty NGINX version.
So basically, what it did, it just
was a demonstration of using a proxy pass feature of NGINX
and capturing the cookies that were going back
from the website to the user.
And it was essentially working as a reverse proxy
that later got popularized the whole term.
Then in the version 2.0, I released as a standalone tool
a year later in 2018.
And until this day, it's been running.
And recently, two weeks ago, I released version 3,
which is more like a quality of life update of Evil Jinx.
I tried to refresh it and add some new features
that I've been working on for the couple of last years.
So how does it work?
How does it work, the reverse proxy
phishing with Evil Jinx?
Not only Evil Jinx, but also other reverse proxy tools.
So basically, what you have to do
is you have to install Evil Jinx on a remote server.
And this server will act both as a client and as a server.
So essentially, it will await connections from your victims,
you can say.
And they will be served the website,
which is actually proxied from the real website.
That's how the reverse proxy thing works.
Same thing as Nginx proxy pass, which actually just
grabs the content and transfers it back to the user.
So we have the user and the internet on the right side.
And what the user does, the user initiates a connection
with your Evil Jinx server over the fake domain.
Not the fake one, but you have to register it
and you have to buy it first.
But essentially, this is like the main point.
You have to have your own registered domain, which
does not look the same as the one you're trying to imitate.
So then the request, all the packets
actually are transferred back.
So there is one TLS connection between the user and the Evil
Jinx server.
And there is also another TLS connection
between Evil Jinx and the destination website.
So basically, what the user does, what Evil Jinx does,
it will handle these two connections
and be able to decrypt all the packets on its own.
So all the packets that come from the user
are basically decrypted on Evil Jinx side.
So it can tell what the requests are holding,
essentially with usernames and passwords.
And then it opens another connection,
trying to become a client on its own,
talking to the target website, and also sending back
the same username and password with the same HTTP request
that it would do normally.
And then what the destination website responds with
is the session token, for example,
if the login was successful.
And this session token is something
that is captured by Evil Jinx.
And that allows us to bypass multi-factor authentication.
So basically, if you take this session code
and you import it into your web browser,
you can get logged into this user's account
without actually knowing even the credentials,
the login and the password.
So what does the user see when they open the phishing page?
They see the address of the page,
which is like in this example, linkedin.fake.com,
because you have to register your own domain.
And this is like the main point of this talk
that I want to focus on.
And the rest is basically what they will get proxied with.
So it essentially looks much better
than I put on the picture,
because it actually makes a copy,
one-to-one copy from the destination site
back to the user.
So the user has no idea of knowing
if the website is actually fake or not,
because it looks exactly the same as the target website.
So how to bypass multi-factor authentication?
So like I said before, mentioned,
the one thing that has to be captured is the session token.
And this is actually not funny like an image.
It is a real image from Linux Tech Tips YouTube video,
as they got recently hacked.
It was not through the phishing attempt,
but it was through installing malware
that actually stole cookies from their production PCs.
And these cookies were then used
to impersonate their YouTube accounts.
And the attackers could then act
on their own in context of their own YouTube accounts.
So what can be done?
The attacks are still highly effective
and not much has really improved over the last six years.
So from, as I'm looking at it,
like there are people saying that you can use YubiKeys,
you can use U2F, you can use Fedos
and all these other things,
but the security responsibility
is put on the side of the user,
which I think is a bad thing
because actually the website developers
should do a better job
and know how to protect their own users
because this is actually what they should be doing.
Like that's the main thing.
So the question remains.
The question that once Scooter asked
that was very important
and that I will try to answer in this talk.
And this is how much is the phish?
Like what is the cost for the attacker
to actually perform a successful phishing operation
and how to raise the cost for the attacker?
So the main weak point of every phishing attempt
is actually the phishing page domain, the phishing domain.
So this is the one,
the thing that you have to register every time.
And this is something that you can,
it has to be always different from the legitimate website.
So if you want to phish, I say like LinkedIn,
you have to, you cannot just register LinkedIn.com
because it's taken.
Otherwise that you could use some
men in the middle kind of attack,
but you'd have to have a TLS certificate
that is the private keys
of the real TLS certificate of LinkedIn.
And you cannot just like that,
impersonate a registered domain.
So you have to have your own.
So this is actually impossible to spoof this domain
without GUI tricks.
So the graphical user interface tricks.
So I'm mentioning this
because Mr. Docs actually released a really great project.
He actually created with HTML and CSS and JavaScript.
He created his like an own visual representation
of a pop-up in Windows.
And this pop-up would actually be rendered
into the web browser,
looking like a real pop-up that Windows would show.
And it would show a normal like page with the real domain.
And all of this was rendered.
So other than that,
the domain can always be verified visually
when you just look at it.
So this is like the thing
that we've been hearing all the time.
Check the domain if it's the phishing domain
and if it's not,
but still the responsibility is like transferred on the user.
So the website developers should be actually doing this job.
And the interesting part is
it can be verified with JavaScript.
So adding the defenses,
like how to make phishing harder
on the side of the web development.
So we have two objects
that are accessible through JavaScript.
This is like window location and document location.
And these objects actually hold all the information
that we need to protect the users.
So we have the host, the host name,
the full URL of the page
that the user is currently visiting.
And it is important to use this
to verify if the user is on the real website.
Because otherwise, if the user just went,
if the user is on the phishing website,
the URL would be just not the real one.
And the owners of the website know
on what domain they actually host the website.
So this is something that we can actually confirm.
So this is, and this is also unspoofable.
So you cannot just write your own JavaScript
and put your own values into this location object.
So it's basically read-only.
So even if you write your JavaScript
and put window.location.host equals something else,
the real domain, then it will not get overwritten.
So this is something, there were some bugs before,
like a long time, long ago in web browsers.
But since the web browsers are now pretty mature,
these bugs have been eradicated.
So client-side JavaScript detections.
This is a simple script
that any website can actually employ.
And it doesn't cost the developers anything
to implement this kind of thing.
So this is just to show you,
this is a regular expression that will look
for .lab.eviljings.com at the end of the,
in the end of the host name here,
using regular expressions.
And if this actually matches, then it will return true.
If it doesn't, it will return false.
And we can implement this execution of this function
in the process of user logging in.
So when the user is trying to log in,
they will get booted out of the whole process
if this domain is not right.
Because it's essentially, there will be an indicator
of a phishing attempt if the domain doesn't match.
And the user should not be allowed to log in.
And thankfully, with JavaScript,
it is such a flexible language
that we can actually obfuscate it even more.
So like, we can turn all the object names,
as you can see, the location, host,
and even the function name, the match, into strings.
And we can then use arrays to also,
to put it like into the expression
and it will be the correct syntax.
And all of these strings that are written here,
the location, host, and match can be later obfuscated.
You can even use something simple as base64
just to not make it look similar.
So how does Eviljinx work?
And how Eviljinx can actually bypass these protections?
Because I implemented a thing that's called subfilters
into Eviljinx.
And how it works is it will take the responses
from the website, and as they go through Eviljinx,
the user who writes a fishlet,
fishlet is like a small script
that's being digested by Eviljinx
to know how to target a specific website,
they can actually write their own regular expression
to find specific strings in the data that was received,
either if it's HTML or JavaScript,
find this data on the specific domain,
and then it can replace it with something else.
So in this example, the example is for the script
that was on the previous slide.
It will look for the regular expression
that tries to look for the proper domain name
at the end of the hosting.
So once it finds it, then it will replace it
with dot and asterisk, which is a regular expression
for anything, essentially.
So how does this script work after the user retrieves it
when it gets parsed by Eviljinx
and how it gets received on the user end
is that the regular expression will be replaced
with just looking for anything.
So this protection is bypassed.
So how can we make it harder still?
So implement dynamic code obfuscation.
It sounds easy, it's maybe not that easy to implement,
but you can use JavaScript obfuscation engines
that are available online, or even write your own,
and just try to make your JavaScript code
harder to read for the attacker.
But of course, it will generate a static version
of this JavaScript.
So still, you can see even here in the middle,
this regular expression, the string was not obfuscated.
So this bypass that Eviljinx will do
will still work and apply in this scenario.
So this is not good enough, still.
Then you need to remember to obfuscate the strings.
So how can JavaScript really obfuscate the strings?
So it can be as simple as using
even simple string concatenation.
So you just grab parts of the string
and you just put plus in between,
like here in this example.
Either you can use replace all,
so just put some random characters inside of your string
and then use replace all to just remove them all together.
So the main trick of why to do it,
like you have to generate a unique version
of this kind of obfuscation for every user
that visits your website.
So that attacker, like me for example, using Eviljinx
will look for known signatures in the JavaScript code
with your protections.
So I will just be looking for, for example,
this regular expression and replace it with my own.
So making sure that every user actually receives
a different version of the website,
me as an attacker have no idea what to look for essentially
because I cannot prepare one fishlet
with one regular expression that will apply
to every obfuscated version of the website
that the user will receive.
So we can even use, as an example,
some Base64 with replace all function calls.
And the key points of increasing the costs
for the attacker, to summarize,
it's like to use the location object
to validate the domain of the currently viewed page.
This is like the most important factor.
Then obfuscate the detection code.
So like I showed you,
like you have to use some kind of JavaScript engine.
It's even good enough to write your own
just to make sure to obfuscate the strings as well
and to deliver unique version of obfuscated JavaScript
to every visitor.
I know that there's an issue with that
because JavaScript likes to be cached on CDNs, for example.
So that way we do not generate additional traffic
when the website loads.
So it doesn't have to be with every page refreshed,
but it would at least be enough
if one user retrieves just one static version,
which is different from the other user
that actually opens the page.
And this version can be still different,
can be still the same across several page opens.
But the most important part is to not let the attacker know
what to expect.
So make it impossible to find
and replace your detection code
with a single regular expression,
because this is how Evil Jinx worked.
I have no way actually to,
I haven't figured out the way how to make it more versatile
in terms of bypassing these kinds of protections.
But I know that currently
all the reverse proxy phishing frameworks,
not only Evil Jinx and even the ones
that are used by cyber criminals and other people,
they will usually just use single regular expression
to look for the protection code to remove it.
And another thing, this is something new
that I wanted to talk about.
I haven't seen anyone actually talk about it before.
And these are secret tokens.
So secret tokens is a kind of like a protection,
which is also client side made in JavaScript,
which adds an extra value into the post request
while you're logging in on the website.
So for example, with the packet HTTP request
that you're sending with your login,
your email and the password,
there will be another value added in the background
with some additional data.
Like it looks encrypted, it's like a blob of data.
And usually this is actually an example
that I took from LinkedIn,
because LinkedIn actually started implementing
this kind of technique and all of the like major websites
I can see that are now implementing similar techniques.
So this encrypted blob of data
calls some client session characteristics.
And we have no idea to know what it is there
because it's actually generated with JavaScript
that they implement on the website.
So we can either reverse engineer this whole process
of how this token is created
so that we can later write our own code into Evil Jinx
that will spoof this token with this whole information.
But the key is that this encrypted blob of data
will hold also the domain that the user
is currently visiting.
And this packet is then sent to the server,
this value, and the server is able to decrypt it
and verify if the user actually accessed the website
from either the phishing domain
or from the legitimate domain.
So it is very similar as using the protection
that I mentioned before,
but it gives it like a different twist to it
because the detection is actually done on the server.
So as an example,
how can you generate this kind of secret token?
So this secret token can actually,
there's one interesting property that I found in the HTML,
every HTML DOM element of the website that it opens,
and this is SSURI.
So as you can see, if you grab any element
that is rendered on the website,
you can grab the base URI property out of it,
and it will give you the origin
of where this element is being rendered on.
So you can use it the same way as window location
because it will always hold the real domain name
of the website that's currently being viewed.
So what we can do is we can iterate
for all the DOM elements, serialize the attribute values,
and put it into a JSON structure,
which later can be encrypted,
encrypted with a passphrase, which is unique to the user.
So it makes a good idea to encrypt it
with some input data that both the user knows
and the server, which can be like a combination
of email and password, for example,
to make it unique across different user.
And this is the basic protection code
that I wrote as an example.
So what it does, it will recursively call the function
element to object, which basically goes
through all of the elements rendered on the website
and grabs the tokens, grabs not the tokens,
but the base URI of every element
that is rendered on the website.
And then it encapsulates it all into one structure
that is later used to be encrypted
and encrypted with the email and password,
and then added to the post request
and sent together with the credentials.
So has it been spotted like in the wild?
So yes, Google uses it, or rather I should say used it.
They had like a kind of protection
that would protect themselves
from headless browser automation.
So what they would do is they had the secret token
embedded within their whole sign-in process,
and it would generate through very high level
of obfuscation, I tried to reverse engineer
this JavaScript code that Google had,
how to, like trying to find out
how this token is generated, but it just made no sense.
So, and this shows how to make it impossible
for the attacker, like to make it too hard
to actually be able to bypass these kind of protections,
just to make it so hard that they actually
will just give up and go and fish some other website,
and that's the only thing.
And what Google used, they used this secret token,
which was like a BotGuard token,
but other than that, at the beginning of this year,
they actually implemented a new version
of their sign-in API, and they removed it.
I have no idea why.
Maybe they are just trying to debug it
and implement some new features and test them first
before trying to implement some better protection.
I don't know, maybe it's still coming,
but it's like several months already,
and this token was not implemented.
Another one is LinkedIn, that I also found out.
So, like I showed you, this AFPC, I think, value,
with the POST request.
The interesting part is that the whole login process
is allowed, even if you are using,
if you're attacking the user through reverse proxy,
Evil Jinx server, for example.
So, the attacker will be, the phished user
will be allowed to log in, but upon successful login,
the account will be immediately locked,
and you will have to unlock it
through going through email verification
and things like that.
So, this is like a very interesting approach,
because it doesn't actually break
the whole sign-in process.
It only makes it impossible,
once the reverse proxy phishing attack is successful,
it will lock an account, because it will detect
that it was using the phishing domain
and not the real one.
So, are secret tokens unspoofable?
So, this is an interesting question,
because, like I explained, you can either
reverse engineer the JavaScript code
to find out how this token is formed,
and then recreate this code to create your own token,
but this takes time, and of course,
if you employ very good JavaScript obfuscation,
which is always possible, and you can only
actually debug it with Google Chrome these days,
and Chrome debugger is essentially like a go-to place
for JavaScript debugging, and still,
I could not use the Chrome debugger to debug,
for example, the Google obfuscated JavaScript code.
So, at that point, it actually makes,
it makes it impossible for the attacker
to be able to remove such protection.
So, kind of.
There is one way that you can imagine,
what if we took another approach,
and actually, while the user is getting phished,
we open another browser in the background,
using the legitimate domain and legitimate website,
and we try to, as the user is entering their credentials,
like, for example, login and password,
it will pause the reverse proxy attempt,
the phishing attempt, and in the background,
using the browser, the real browser,
using the legitimate, the real domain,
it will try to log into the user's account,
and grab this secret token that's generated
in the legitimate session, and then grab this token,
like, break the execution of this real login attempt
that's happening in the background,
and just grab this token, and paste it
into the reverse proxy phishing session.
Eventually, if, so, this is the thing
that I want to demo right now.
I have a video, I didn't prepare live demos,
but essentially, then the demo gods will be okay with that.
Here you can see,
on the top right, we have Evil Jinx terminal running,
installed on the remote server.
On the bottom right, we have the login page
of the user who's being currently phished.
You can see there is the domain name
of accounts.google.fake.com,
and on the left side, we have this background browser
that is opened on the side of Evil Jinx,
on the attacker's server, that's waiting for user input.
And what happens now, you can see quickly,
when the user enters their login, and presses enter,
the background browser will open the legitimate website,
which you can see, it's accounts.google.com, like here,
and it will copy all of the actions on behalf of the user.
So, it will enter the login, so you can see,
it entered the login, it was allowed,
and at the same time, the session token
is actually being captured, well, not the session,
the secret token, is being captured
from this background browser, and injected
into the reverse proxy session
on the side of the phished user.
So, you can see, the phished user
is also getting through the protections,
otherwise, Google would just say
that something went wrong, if this token
that was captured from the background was invalid,
and the user can continue to get phished.
So, then the user enters their password,
and the background browser mimics the same thing.
You could see it happened really fast,
because it actually entered the password,
and then broke the connection,
so that the user would not retrieve double information
that someone tried to log into their account.
And then, in the proxy session,
you can see that there is now,
the Google is now awaiting for two-step verification
over the fake domain, so at this point,
I would open my phone as a phished user, and accept it,
and you can see that we are successfully logged in,
and when the session is actually being listed,
then it shows you that the session was properly captured.
So, this is one idea of what can be done

So, to recap.
Yeah.
Well, it wasn't a live demo, though, but yeah.
So, to recap.
On the defender side,
we have to validate the domain with JavaScript,

Then, we obfuscate the code,
then we obfuscate the strings, and then we randomize.
So, this is the most important part, actually,

On the attacker side, it will increase the cost
